0.16.text:
Hello everybody, Claudia Boleyn here and today
this is going to be a sort of review/critique

4.08.text:
video about Marvel's Age of Ultron the new
Avengers film which I went to see on my birthday

10.25.text:
and have seen a couple of times since. This
is mostly going to be a critique so it's going

14.71.text:
to be 5 things that I found not quite right
about the film or I personally would have

19.88.text:
changed, it's completely subjective so you
don't have to agree with any of this it's

23.15.text:
just my opinion and also I just have to add
before I start that I really did love the

28.59.text:
film. Genuinely it's one of my favourite films
of all time and a lot of people are saying

33.69.text:
it doesn't quite stand up to the first Avengers
film, for me it's much better than that but

37.76.text:
then again it did have my three, actually
it had four of my favourite, Avengers, Marvel

44.00.text:
characters of all time in it. So that's Pietro,
Wanda, the Vision and Peggy who is kind of

48.66.text:
fleetingly in the film. Oh I should probably
say at this point that obviously there's gonna

53.14.text:
be spoilers, I'm sure you know that, but yeah,
if you haven't seen the film yet then don't

57.29.text:
watch this. Why are you even watching this
video anyway? Go and watch the film and then

60.22.text:
come back and watch this later.
My first problem with this film is the treatment

63.54.text:
of Natasha Romanoff, that's Black Widow and
one of my favourite Marvel characters. This

67.69.text:
is a very contentious issue and this is really
controversial in the Marvel fandom at the

71.17.text:
moment. It's kind of split the fandom. Basically
people are arguing about whether Natasha's

76.40.text:
role was feminist enough or whether she was
wasted in the storyline. Now I've seen quite

82.35.text:
a few videos and critiques by other bloggers
and vloggers and Youtubers that I really admire

89.73.text:
on this, but I've come to a different opinion
to quite a few of them actually. I really

94.60.text:
really think that Natasha was let down in
this film and that's just my opinion. I feel

98.97.text:
like she was worth so much more than the plot
line she was given. Now I wanna make it really

103.18.text:
clear that I don't have a problem with a female
character having a love story as their plot

107.84.text:
line whatsoever, honestly I don't mind. You
know I'm a fierce supporter of women like

111.84.text:
Sansa Stark who are very romantic and traditionally
feminine. I mean my favourite Marvel character

116.74.text:
is actually Wanda Maximoff and she's very
feminine really she's very feminine coded

121.31.text:
and I love her for that, I think she's wonderful.
My problem with the fact that Natasha's story

126.53.text:
was a love story is not that it was a love
story. I don't think that a love story should

130.78.text:
be any lesser than some sort of other plot
line. A lot of people seem to think oh it's

135.34.text:
a love story it's boring it's useless, and
that's a wrong way to think because no a love

140.05.text:
story, if done in the right way can be really
interesting and great and it's another, it's

144.38.text:
another part of this misogyny and internalised
misogyny we've got going on where things that

149.23.text:
we link to femininity and emotion we kind
of look down on and we kind of appreciate

154.62.text:
the masculine traits more even us women because
we have internalised misogyny. An example

159.00.text:
of this is how people will think Arya Stark
is way cooler than Sansa Stark basically because

165.30.text:
Arya's gone for the more masculine gender
role whereas Sansa shows the more feminine

170.47.text:
gender role. Both are, this is not the topic
of today, but both are very strong female

175.50.text:
characters in different ways, they're both
excellent female characters actually that

180.41.text:
I ado re, but they're both strong in different
ways. Sansa isn't any less of a strong female

183.28.text:
character just because she is more feminine.
So my issue is not the fact that Natasha had

186.82.text:
a love plot line. My issues are that, it was
A, her only plot line, and B, that she was

192.63.text:
paired with Bruce Banner. Because to start
with we already have two men in the Marvel

197.91.text:
Cinematic Universe with whom Natasha Romanoff
is canonically linked. So we have Matt Murdock

202.10.text:
from Daredevil, and we also have Bucky Barnes
who is the Winter Soldier. So it kind of baffles

206.95.text:
me that she's been paired with Bruce. I don't
think that it's very true to her character

210.69.text:
to pair her with Bruce which makes me kind
of think that Joss Whedon, when writing this

215.46.text:
film, didn't know what to do with her, thought
oh well I guess the Hulk kind of needs someone

220.44.text:
to look after him, we'll kind of put Natasha
in with Bruce. And that's why it doesn't work

224.81.text:
for me. Had Natasha's story been a love story
with one of the characters that I feel would

229.95.text:
reflect someone was actually looking at her
personality and writing her well, I wouldn't

233.65.text:
mind it whatsoever. I mean I'm a bit supporter
of the whole Winter Widow thing so that's

237.84.text:
Bucky and Natasha and I was very disappointed
by the Bruce and Natasha thing.

242.72.text:
Natasha can fall in love if she wants, female
characters falling in love is not a problem

247.29.text:
for me, but I think it's so disrespectful
to her character to imply that she would run

252.49.text:
away from her duty like that and just disappear
off into the sunset with Bruce Banner who

258.38.text:
she's previously showed no interest in whatsoever.
I really did spend a lot of the film thinking

263.63.text:
she was working with Tony undercover to secretly
get rid of Bruce and send him to space. Spoiler

269.50.text:
alert, in the comics they do actually send
him to space, poor Hulk, poor Bruce, cause

273.64.text:
he's causing chaos. I thought that was what
was going on so I was really stunned by the

277.01.text:
whole Black Widow and Bruce Banner storyline.
Also there are two very problematic scenes

281.51.text:
here for me. One is the fact that Natasha
is reduced to a damsel in distress. I can

286.11.text:
understand her being against Ultron and not
being able to fight against Ultron, he's a

290.13.text:
very strong villain, baddie, whatever you
wanna call him, but once she's been left in

294.83.text:
her cage in Sokovia she needs Bruce to break
her out. Now again, I don't have a problem

303.47.text:
with women being damsels in distress and being
saved by a man, that doesn't make someone

308.40.text:
a weak character, but for Natasha Romanoff
in particular this is so disrespectful. Are

313.46.text:
you trying to imply that Natasha Romanoff,
the Black Widow would not be able to break

318.30.text:
herself out of a cell that is not being attended
by anyone, really?

322.08.text:
And then there's possibly the worst part of
this whole storyline in the film where Bruce

326.93.text:
is talking about how difficult he's finding
life and he sees himself as a monster because

330.92.text:
he does really turn into a big green rage
monster whenever he's angry and he causes

334.23.text:
lots of chaos. Poor Bruce. I do like Bruce.
I feel very sorry for him. But then Natasha

339.92.text:
talks to Bruce about this and ends up talking
about her forced sterilisation as part of

344.63.text:
her training in the Red Room when she was
training to be Black Widow. And it really

349.47.text:
disturbed me that the fact she was made infertile
was in any way compared to Bruce Banner being

356.48.text:
a monster. Now it might just have been the
way it came across on screen but for me I

360.58.text:
felt like there was a comparison being made
there and that's incredibly disturbing. It

364.89.text:
kind of implied that the reason that Black
Widow was so fearsome, or she'd be less of

370.18.text:
a bad character, less of a monstrous character
if she was able to have children. Which is

374.12.text:
obviously a very dangerous message because
being able to have children doesn't change

378.82.text:
your worth in the slightest, it certainly
doesn't make you a monster and I just think

382.38.text:
maybe that scene needed more context or something
because the way that was read really really

386.92.text:
disturbed me.
Now for the people saying that okay it's a

389.81.text:
big film and they had lots to do and there
was nothing else Natasha could have done in

392.53.text:
this film, I can think of a million and one
things Natasha could have done in this film.

397.71.text:
I mean, to start with she's dealing with the
fact that all her personal information, her

401.85.text:
entire background was leaked at the end of
Winter Soldier, which is a fantastic film

405.67.text:
and the Russo brothers did so well with that
and I'm so glad they're taking over for Civil

409.47.text:
War again, amazing. But I mean that's a big
thing for her to deal with, isn't it? Suddenly

413.13.text:
being in the public eye and having to face
up to what she's done and people knowing who

416.06.text:
she is. that could have been a big plot line
for her. Now second of all I feel like Clint

420.64.text:
Barton took a lot of the story that could
have gone to Natasha. Obviously Clint Barton

426.59.text:
acted as a sort of, well in a way he kind
of guided Wanda at some points, he spent a

431.76.text:
lot of time with the Maximoff twins and he
seemed to empathise with them and he was the

435.46.text:
one who gave Wanda her big hero speech, you
know: If you step out of that door you're

438.63.text:
an Avenger. Surely, I mean for me if I was
writing it I would form a friendship between

443.61.text:
Natasha and Wanda and I think it would have
been more poignant had Natasha been the one

446.93.text:
to give that speech. After all Natasha knows
what it's like to become a weapon for your

452.32.text:
country, she knows what it's like to be used,
she's from Eastern Europe same as Wanda and

457.21.text:
Pietro, she understands making a mistake and
wanting to atone for that so desperately and

462.08.text:
trying to be good again and being given that
chance. Wouldn't that have been far more fantastic

465.37.text:
if that role had been given to Natasha instead
of Clint? Now also with regard to the Black

468.96.text:
Widow/Natasha Romanoff writing issue I have
to bring up the thing that's happened with

473.08.text:
Joss Whedon at the moment. Joss Whedon has
come of twitter, I'm not sure why he came

477.89.text:
off twitter, I think maybe he just felt like
it was easier to be more creative when he

481.32.text:
was more private, I don't know, but there
was a statement he made which I just wanted

486.06.text:
to read out and I'm not sure I agree with
it. This is a direct quote: "I've said before

489.64.text:
when you declare yourself politically you
destroy yourself artistically because suddenly

494.21.text:
that's the litmus test for everything you
do. For example, in my case, feminism. If

498.29.text:
you don't live up to the litmus test of feminism
in this one instance then you're a misogynist.

502.41.text:
It circles directly back upon you."
I think this is a bit of a cop out statement

506.10.text:
from Joss Whedon because if you declare yourself
a feminist and you want to be a feminist icon,

511.04.text:
you even declare you don't like the name feminism
and you want to rebrand it because it doesn't

514.42.text:
suit you well enough, I'm sorry but you've
got to, you've got to deliver on the goods.

519.16.text:
If you want to be known as a feminist writer,
that's great, and Joss Whedon has done some

523.10.text:
great stuff… a while ago. I feel like feminism
has moved on past Joss Whedon, he's not moving

528.18.text:
with it. Does he still deserve the title of
being a great feminist hero if he's not really

533.53.text:
delivering the goods anymore? I don't know
if he does, I think that people, all of us,

537.98.text:
I'm not just trying to be harsh on Joss Whedon
in particular here, all of us have to move

541.37.text:
with the movement. We have to make sure that
we're being as inclusive as possible, we're

544.96.text:
listening to people, we're growing, we're
opening our minds. We don't have the right

548.29.text:
to just label ourself a feminist and then
complain if we mess up. I think it would have

552.52.text:
been far better of Joss Whedon to accept the
criticism, even if he disagreed with it and,

556.53.text:
and just say, okay, I hold my hands up, maybe
I didn't think about some stuff, maybe I could

561.21.text:
have done it differently. So I was very disappointed
by that response from him.

563.73.text:
My second issue with Age of Ultron was actually
Clint Barton and his storyline. Now again

567.77.text:
it sounds really bad and I know the way it
comes across. It sounds really, like I'm full

573.66.text:
of internalised misogyny here, but the issue
for me was the fact that Clint had a family.

577.61.text:
Now let me elaborate on this. It sounds like
I'm really anti the idea of having a traditional

581.97.text:
family and that kind of thing. I'm really
really not, but I am anti that idea surrounding

586.48.text:
Clint Barton in particular as a character.
I just think it's incredibly misjudged. I

591.40.text:
read the Hawkeye comics where he and Kate
Bishop get up to all sorts of trouble and

596.65.text:
it's really fun and great and the Hawkeye
I know and love is a bit of a mess really.

601.65.text:
I mean he lives in an apartment and he loves
dogs and he has Pizza Dog and he's just a

607.24.text:
bit of a mess and he's really endearing and
lovely and suddenly in the film he becomes

610.54.text:
this ideal American family man with two kids,
a girl and a boy and another kid on the way,

616.23.text:
and his wife is living on a farm by herself
somewhere, why you'd want to do that I don't

621.74.text:
know, maybe some people would but it's all
very strange. I just don't think the portrayal

625.26.text:
of Clint Barton in this film reflected what
the real Clint Barton is like and again that's

629.41.text:
subjective because I know the Marvel Cinematic
Universe is allowed to take some liberties

633.55.text:
with this and to change things up, I just
think that was a huge mistake and very very

638.55.text:
odd. Now it does seem a little weirdly heteronormative
for me personally, the idea of Clint having

644.20.text:
a family, having a wife and the kids, living
the American ideal on a farm and it's lovely

649.66.text:
and his wife's just getting on with milking
the cows and fixing the tractor. The striking

656.23.text:
part of this is, for me, when Tony towards
the end of the film says that he'd like to

660.23.text:
get a farm like this for Pepper and that's
when I was struck by how heteronormative this

664.14.text:
is and bullshitty. Pepper Potts, are you actually
kidding me, Tony? Pepper Potts, CEO of Stark

669.72.text:
Industries, you're gonna put her on a farm?
You think she's going to want to live on a

673.28.text:
farm in the middle of nowhere? It's just a
total mess and it feels like Joss Whedon's

677.98.text:
idea of the perfect peaceful life he's kind
of thrust onto those characters and I just

682.91.text:
don't think that stands anymore.
Also I think way too much time in this film

685.96.text:
is taken up with Clint Barton and his family
living in this lovely little farm somewhere

690.48.text:
and I just don't think it made any narrative
sense whatsoever. I read in an interview that

694.83.text:
Joss Whedon was all excited because he was
going to try and trick the audience into thinking

698.09.text:
that it's going to be Hawkeye that dies at
the end, and then suddenly shocking us all

702.16.text:
when it's not him, and I just think why bother
wasting all that time with Hawkeye living

707.91.text:
in domestic bliss on a farm somewhere, why
waste that time it was just so dull.

712.44.text:
I have no problem with Laura, his wife, either,
nor do I have a problem with women who want

716.40.text:
to play that housewifey kind of role, I mean
if that's what you wanna do that's fine, I

721.48.text:
just don't think that's the sort of thing
that Hawkeye would have in his backstory really.

727.09.text:
Also we've had Bobbi Morse who's Mockingbird
introduced into the Marvel Cinematic Universe

732.08.text:
in Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D. who is canonically
Clint's wife, so I was assuming they were

737.96.text:
gonna put them together. Maybe now they're
not which is a real shame for me so yeah that

741.63.text:
kind of irritated me a bit.
Third thing that bothered me about Age of

743.93.text:
Ultron was the fact that there were still
so few people of colour in it. I mean we have

747.53.text:
Rhodey, James Rhodes who is War Machine, and
we have Sam Wilson, Falcon, who is one of

751.55.text:
my favourite characters, I really love Sam
Wilson, I have a soft spot for him. They were

755.69.text:
barely in this film, I mean they were there
like socialising but when it was like the

759.32.text:
big battle sequence I felt like they were
hardly around and it just bugged me a lot

764.12.text:
because I feel like they could have had a
lot more screen time. These are characters

767.70.text:
that people love and I don't know it just,
it rubs me up the wrong way to be perfectly

774.21.text:
honest that the team is still so very white,
especially as, and this is a point I'm gonna

778.67.text:
get to in a bit, I mean Pietro and Wanda are
being kind of whitewashed in this film anyway,

785.09.text:
I'll get to that in a second I'll explain
the sort of ins and outs of that and my opinion

789.02.text:
on that, but we could really have done with
some more representation there and for me

793.62.text:
it wasn't good enough to just have Rhodey
fly in at the end and I mean Sam was barely

798.12.text:
in it. Sam just sort of turned up at the end
as an Avenger, the new Avengers team looks

802.01.text:
great by the way, I love the set of characters
involved in that, but I just think it's quite

806.34.text:
shameful that we're at this point and we're
still, well the representation is still so

811.10.text:
poor. There's no other way to put it, I mean
people will say I'm making a big deal out

814.80.text:
of this but I just really feel like… what's
going on here? What is going on? I mean how

820.25.text:
long was this film in the making for? Did
nobody think look we have got War Machine

825.54.text:
and Falcon let's bloody well use them. Apparently
not.

828.52.text:
Okay so my last two issues with this film
are both gonna be about the Maximoffs who

832.82.text:
are my favourite characters in the Marvel
universe so this is something that's very

837.09.text:
close to my heart actually. Okay so the two
things I'm gonna talk about here are A, spoiler

843.16.text:
alert, Pietro's death and B, the 'whitewashing'
of the Maximoff twins. Now I haven't got an

848.92.text:
issue with the fact that the Maximoffs in
the MCU are kind of pale skinned because a

854.45.text:
lot of Jewish Roma people are pale skinned
and that's absolutely fine. The issue I have

859.02.text:
here is that Elizabeth Olsen, who plays the
most fantastic Wanda, she is a wonderful actress,

865.20.text:
I adore her, but she isn't Jewish and I think
this is kind of problematic, I also think

870.91.text:
it's very problematic, the fact that they're
Jewish and Roma, these two characters is not

875.43.text:
actually touched upon in the film at all.
Now this baffles me. This is an absolutely

879.95.text:
massive massive film that so many people are
going to see. How easy would it have been

884.31.text:
to just put in one line about them being Jewish
or Roma? Because there's so much antisemitism

890.47.text:
at the moment, and also there's a lot of hatred
against people from Eastern Europe. How brilliant

896.16.text:
would it have been to just say, look, these
two heroes right here, these two heroes are

900.99.text:
Jewish, they're Roma, they're Eastern European,
you're going to have to deal with it. I absolutely

904.33.text:
understand that there's a problem and that
Magneto can't be their father in this instance

908.19.text:
which is a real shame cause I love that plot
line, but there is no reason why in this version

912.59.text:
they can't still be Jewish and Roma. I don't
understand. A massive massive part of their

917.92.text:
characters is their identity as Roma and Jewish
people, and to take that away really does

922.74.text:
feel like a slap in the face. Also, the idea
of two Jewish characters voluntarily going

929.23.text:
to Hydra, who's like a neo-nazi organisation
in order to be experimented on really creeps

936.04.text:
me out, I do not think that idea was thought
out at all, I think that is in very bad taste

940.42.text:
and I did not like it.
Could the Maximoff twins not have been tricked

943.43.text:
into it? Could they not have been captured?
Could they not have fought their way out?

947.02.text:
Just the idea of having these two massively
popular Jewish characters who their being

951.81.text:
Jewish is such a huge part of who they are,
voluntarily joining up with the neo-nazis,

957.38.text:
especially with a character lie Scarlet Witch
who can read what's in people's minds so she

961.36.text:
knows what these people are up to and who
they are. It's just really really poorly thought

965.85.text:
out, I think and I don't like it at all.
And the last issue I have with this film:

969.76.text:
Pietro Maximoff's death. Now I cried so much
in the cinema when this happened because I

974.12.text:
am a massive massive fan of Quicksilver. He
is not a perfect character by any stretch

979.65.text:
of the imagination, he's not the sort of character
that you should really idolise, especially

983.55.text:
not in the comics I mean he has a lot of flaws,
but that's what I love about him. I love the

987.00.text:
sibling relationship between him and Wanda
and I just think he's brilliant. He's come

992.70.text:
from a very troubled life and I have this
comic series which I got on ebay which is

997.25.text:
called Son of M, so it's like the events after
House of M where Wanda gets rid of the mutants.

1002.14.text:
I don't know if you're a comics reader but
at one point in the comics Wanda is so distressed

1006.45.text:
at losing her two children that she has with
the Vision that she says 'No more mutants'

1011.43.text:
and all the mutants lose their power. Basically
Son of M is what happens to Quicksilver after

1015.89.text:
losing his powers so it's really great and
you should give it a read, it's definitely

1020.33.text:
great if you're a Quicksilver fan. I know
a lot of people have become Quicksilver fans

1023.27.text:
now. I don't understand why Pietro had to
die, to be perfectly honest. I'm really gutted

1028.27.text:
cause Wanda and Pietro, for me, are a double
act and I would have liked more Wanda and

1033.19.text:
Pietro in the film, although their portrayals
in this film were spot on. They were perfect.

1039.49.text:
I really really don't think they could be
faulted in any way for their performances,

1044.52.text:
Elizabeth Olsen and Aaron Taylor Johnson.
Just every little movement and expression

1049.26.text:
was so dead on that watching it makes me really
emotional because they really translated so

1054.82.text:
well those characters from the comics. The
mannerisms and everything were just fantastic.

1058.71.text:
But Quicksilver is a very popular character.
For people who didn't know who Quicksilver

1062.93.text:
was, I've asked a lot of people when they
came out of the film, you know, friends and

1066.33.text:
things, 'so, who's your favourite Avenger?'
and most of them, genuinely most people are

1071.75.text:
saying, 'oh, Quicksilver, he was so cool,
I can't believe he had to die!'

1074.92.text:
I agree. I can't believe he had to die. I
think he had a lot more to give. I think his

1080.18.text:
relationship with Wanda is a massive part
of Wanda and I think it's a shame to lose

1085.10.text:
that. I also really wanted to see Pietro getting
a bit jealous with the Vision and Wanda thing

1089.50.text:
going on. I'm such a big Vision and Wanda
shipper, you have no idea. Or maybe you do

1093.38.text:
have an idea if you follow me on tumblr, cause
I post a lot about that, I just love them.

1097.68.text:
The only consolation I have here is that it's
rumoured that Wanda's going to be in the new

1101.25.text:
Dr Strange film which would be great because
more Wanda is great with me, I love Wanda,

1107.50.text:
she's my favourite, and I'm hoping that she's
going to be learning more about her powers

1110.73.text:
and I'm really hoping that she's going to
try and bring Pietro back because in the comics,

1115.19.text:
I don't know if you read the comics with Wanda,
the Scarlet Witch, but she feels emotions

1120.63.text:
very strongly but she can lose control of
them and she can lose control of her powers

1123.75.text:
and when she loses certain people she tries
to bring them back and it creates a lot of

1128.80.text:
chaos and it's very dangerous so I would love
to see that happen with Wanda in the MCU,

1133.99.text:
I'd love to see her trying desperately to
bring Pietro back because, you know, I think

1137.50.text:
that's what Wanda would do if they're being
true to her character I think she'd do anything

1141.09.text:
to get Pietro back. Also all is not lost because
we have the Infinity Gauntlet that can bring

1146.31.text:
people back to life. We can live in hope.
So let's not lose hope completely about Pietro

1150.53.text:
because I think from the response in this
film they must know at Marvel how popular

1155.09.text:
he is and how much people want to see more
of him. Apparently they even filmed an alternate

1159.18.text:
sequence where he recovers with Dr Cho after
being shot at and he has a new costume and

1165.26.text:
everything and he's on the new Avengers lineup,
so all is not lost, we can be really hopeful

1168.91.text:
there. Also I just have to say one more thing,
this is a guy who catches a bullet in midair

1173.06.text:
and puts it down on the table and yet when
the bullets are raining down on Clint and

1176.75.text:
that kid Pietro somehow has to use his body
to shield them, he has to take the bullets

1183.38.text:
himself. This would all be avoided, of course,
if we had the Pietro from X Men Days of Future

1188.40.text:
Past who would have destroyed Ultron before
anyone had even blinked but there you go.

1192.79.text:
Okay, thank you for watching my sort of critique/view
of Age of Ultron. I have to say again I loved

1197.77.text:
the film. There are so many more things I
liked about it than disliked but these are

1201.55.text:
the things I had maybe a little problem with
and I didn't particularly like. Comments are

1206.49.text:
open as usual for you to you know, express
your opinions, no abuse please, again this

1211.31.text:
is completely subjective, it's all from my
head, exactly what I think, and what I think

1215.99.text:
is not always right so that's fine if you
have a different opinion to me. Okay, thank

1219.30.text:
you so much for watching this and I love you
loads. Bye! xxx
